intro: Calandrinia galapagosa, commonly known as the Galápagos morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the Galápagos Islands. It belongs to the family Mallow (Malvaceae) and is characterized by its distinctive, showy flowers that range in color from pink to red. The plant typically grows in coastal areas and is adapted to the arid climate of the islands. Its leaves are hairy and oval-shaped, while its stems are erect and branching. Calandrinia galapagosa plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, providing nectar for local pollinators.
